case_name: State of Bihar v. Bhagirath Sharma and Radhey Shyam Sharma

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 7 of 1970 filed by State of Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 7 of 1970. Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated August 14, 1969 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1055 of 1969.

facts.text: Appeal by certificate from Patna High Court judgment dated August 14, 1969 in Criminal Revision No. 1055 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by certificate from the judgment and order dated August 14, 1969 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1055 of 1969. P. Jha, for the appellant. Sarjoo Prasad and S. N. Prasad, for the respondents.

facts.text: Patna High Court quashed prosecution of Bhagirath Sharma and Radhey Shyam Sharma on revision under ss. 439/561-A Cr.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and order of a learned Single Judge of the Patna High Court dated August 14, 1969 quashing, on revision under ss. 439/561-A, Cr.P.C., the prosecution of Bhagirath Sharma and Radhey Shyam Sharma, the respondents in this Court,

facts.text: Prosecution for contravention of clauses 3, 4 and 5 of the Bihar Essential Commodities Act-other than Foodgrains-Prices and Stocks Display and Control Order, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: for companytravention of clauses 3, 4 and 5 of the Bihar Essential Commodities Act-other than Foodgrains-Prices and Stocks Display and Control Order, 1967 hereinafter called the order , pending in the Court of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Gaya.

facts.text: Proprietor of M/s. Auto Spare, Law Road, Gaya, not properly maintaining account of Motor Tyres.

anchor.surface_text: According to the prosecution case, on receipt of companyfidential information that the proprietor of M s. Auto Spare, Law Road, Gaya, was number properly maintaining the account of Motor Tyres, with the ulterior motive of withholding the supply of the said article to the genuine customers,

facts.text: Surprise inspection by Shri Ram Nivas Singh, Marketing Officer, Gaya, along with two supply Inspectors on May 22, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Ram Nivas Singh, Marketing Officer, Gaya, had, along with two supply Inspectors, made a surprise inspection of the firm on May 22, 1969 and found certain irregularities.

facts.text: Failure to display price list and stock position of Motor Tyres in contravention of clause 4.

anchor.surface_text: One of those irregularities was, the failure of the, firm to display the price list and stock position of Motor Tyres anywhere in their shop, in companytravention of clause 4 of the order.

facts.text: 487 Motor Tyres found stored in inner portion of the shop.

anchor.surface_text: On search by the said Marketing Officer. a huge stock of Motor Tyres of different varieties numbering 487 were actually found stored in the inner portion of the shop.

facts.text: Complaint filed against Bhagirath Sharma and Radhey Shyam Sharma on May 23, 1969 in Court of Sub-Divisional Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: Complaint to that effect was accordingly made in the Court of the Sub-Divisional Magistrate on May 23, 1969.

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Officer, Sadar, Gaya took cognizance under S.7 Essential Commodities Act on May 23, 1969 and transferred to Shri N.N. Singh, Munsif Magistrate 1st Class, Gaya.

anchor.surface_text: On the same date, the Sub-Divisional Officer, Sadar, Gaya after pursuing the report of the Marketing Officer, took companynizance of the case under S. 7 of the Essential Commodities Act and transferred it for disposal to the Court of Shri N. N. Singh, Munsif Magistrate, 1st Class, Gaya.

facts.text: Respondents approached Patna High Court under ss. 439/561-A Cr.P.C. against magistrate's order.

anchor.surface_text: lit is against this order of the Magistrate that the respondents in this Court approached the Patna High Court under ss. 439/561-A, Cr.P.C.

facts.text: Patna High Court Single Judge bound by earlier decision dated April 20, 1969 in Criminal Misc. Case No. 1479 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: A learned Single Judge of the High Court after referring to the two relevant items Nos. 1 5 of Schedule 1 appended to the Order felt bound by an earlier Single Bench decision dated April 20, 1969 of that High Court in Criminal Misc. Case No. 1479 of 1968

facts.text: Item No. 1 of Schedule 1: Component parts and accessories of automobiles.

anchor.surface_text: In this Court, our attention has been drawn to item No. 1 in Schedule 1 of the Order. This item reads - Component parts and accessories of auto- mobiles.

facts.text: Item No. 5 of Schedule 1: Cycle tyres and tubes, including cycle rickshaw tyres and tubes.

anchor.surface_text: The other item to which reference was made by the High Court in the impugned judgment is item No. 5 which reads Cycle tyres and tubes, including cycle rickshaw tyres and tubes .

facts.text: State argues item 1 covers Tyres and Tubes of Motor Cars and Motor Cycles.

anchor.surface_text: It is companytended that this item must companyer Tyres and Tubes of Motor Cars and Motor Cycles. According to the argument forcibly pressed on behalf of the State of Bihar,

facts.text: Gazette Notification No. G.S.R. 82 dated September 18, 1970 added item No. 11: Tyres and tubes of cars, buses, jeeps, etc.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent has also brought to our numberice a Gazette Notification No. G.S.R. 82 dated September 18, 1970 published in the Bihar Government Gazette Extraordinary dated September 22, 1970 according to which four items were added after item No. 9 in Schedule II of the Order. The new item No. 11 reads Tyres and tubes of cars, buses, jeeps, vans, trucks, automobiles of any category whatsoever, tractors and tractor-trollies.

facts.text: Patna High Court granted certificate under Article 134(1)(c) on oral request.

anchor.surface_text: Unfortunately, even the High Court has made a laconic order on oral request, merely stating IT IS CERTIFIED That this case fulfills the requirement of Article 134 1 c of the Constitution of India and is fit for appeal to the Supreme Court.

facts.text: Earlier notification dated January 11, 1968 No.S.C.218 by Ministry of Commerce mentioned Tyres and Tubes of Scooters distinctly.

anchor.surface_text: Now in the judgement in Criminal Misc. Case No. 1479/68, reference was made to a Notification dated January 11, 1968 No.S.C.218 issued by the Ministry of Commerce, Government of India in which Types and Tubes of Scooters were expressly mentioned as essential companymodities distinct from the companyponent parts and accessories of automobiles.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On the-view that we have taken, the High Court seems to us to .have been fully justified in recording the respondents acquittal and we see numbercogent ground for disagreeing with it. The appeal accordingly fails and is. dismissed.

facts.text: Court holds that the Order does not clearly cover Tyres and Tubes of Motor Cars.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the drafting precedents furnished by the other Notifications companysidered in the- earlier decision of the, High Court in Crl. Misc. Case No. 1470/68 do indicate that the draftsman did number intend the scheduled items in the Order as in force in May, 1969 to companyer Tyres and Tubes of Motor Cars.

anchor.surface_text: it was felt that prima facie case had been made out against the partners of the said firm, Shri Bhagirath Sharma and Shri Radhey Shyam Sharma, respondents in this Court, for companytravention of clauses 3, 4 and 5 of the Order.

facts.text: High Court held prosecution misconceived as item 1 does not cover Motor Tyres.

anchor.surface_text: holding that item No. 1 of Schedule 1 companyld number be assumed to companyer the companymodities like Motor Tyres and Motor Tubes though he himself thought that he would have taken a different view,

issues.text: Whether item No. 1 'Component parts and accessories of automobiles' in Schedule I to the Order covers tyres and tubes of motor cars and motor cycles?

anchor.surface_text: In this Court, our attention has been drawn to item No. 1 in Schedule 1 of the Order. This item reads - Component parts and accessories of auto- mobiles. It is contended that this item must cover Tyres and Tubes of Motor Cars and Motor Cycles. According to the argument forcibly pressed on behalf of the State of Bihar,

issues.text: Whether the legal mandate contained in the Order is expressed with such certainty and clarity as to give reasonably precise and adequate guidance to those who want to be law-abiding and lay down an ascertainable standard of guilt by unambiguously specifying the Tyres and Tubes of Motor Cars as a Scheduled item?

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the drafting precedents furnished by the other Notifications considered in the- earlier decision of the, High Court  in Crl. Misc. Case No. 1470/68  do indicate that the draftsman did not intend the scheduled items in the Order as in force in May, 1969 to cover Tyres and Tubes of Motor Cars. But independently of this aspect the question may also be considered from another point of view, viz., if the legal mandate

arguments.claim: Item No. 1 of Schedule I ('Component parts and accessories of automobiles') covers tyres and tubes of motor cars and motor cycles as essential component parts

anchor.surface_text: In this Court, our attention has been drawn to item No. 1 in Schedule 1 of the Order. This item reads - Component parts and accessories of auto- mobiles. It is contended that this item must cover Tyres and Tubes of Motor Cars and Motor Cycles. According to the argument forcibly pressed on behalf of the State of Bihar, Tyres and Tubes of automobiles are their essential component parts and the earlier Single Bench decision of the Patna High Court  in Criminal Misc. Case No. 1479/1958  followed as a binding precedent in the present case should be held to have been wrongly decided.

arguments.court_reasoning: Drafting precedents from other notifications indicate draftsman did not intend to cover motor tyres and tubes; vagueness prevents clear mandate

anchor.surface_text: Tyres and Tubes of automobiles are their essential component parts and the earlier Single Bench decision of the Patna High Court in Criminal Misc. Case No. 1479/1958 followed as a binding precedent in the present case should be held to have been wrongly decided.

Case No. 1479 of 1968 holding that item No. 1 of Schedule 1 could not be assumed to cover the commodities like Motor Tyres and Motor Tubes though he himself thought that he would have taken a different view, had the matter been res integra.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent has also brought to our notice a Gazette Notification No. G.S.R. 82 dated September 18, 1970 published in the Bihar Government Gazette Extraordinary dated September 22, 1970 according to which four items were added after item No. 9 in Schedule II of the Order. The new item No. 11 reads Tyres and tubes of cars, buses, jeeps, vans, trucks, automobiles of any category whatsoever, tractors and tractor-trollies.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: mber to be granted so as to companyvert this Court into an ordinary companyrt of further appeal. We do number find any material on the record suggesti

arguments.court_reasoning: Confirms Order now comprehensive but effect limited to prior prosecutions

arguments.claim: Drafting precedents from other notifications (e.g., 1968, 1969) show tyres and tubes expressly listed separately from component parts, indicating no intent to cover motor tyres under item 1

anchor.surface_text: Now in the judgement in Criminal Misc. Case No. 1479/68, reference was made to a Notification dated January 11, 1968 No.S.C.218 issued by the Ministry of Commerce, Government of India in which Types and Tubes of Scooters were expressly mentioned as essential commodities distinct from the component parts and accessories of automobiles. Reference in that judgment was also made to a Notification dated August 22, 1968 No. S.Q. 2878 issued by the Central Government in which similarly Tyres and Tubes of Cars, etc. were specifically mentioned as essential commodities, and to a still later Notification by the Central Government dated January 3, 1969 No. S.O. 85 in which Tyres and Tubes of Cars were mentioned in a manner almost similar to the one, found in the Bihar Government Gazette Notification No. S.R. 82 dated September 18, 1970.

arguments.claim: The Order lacks certainty and clarity in specifying motor tyres as scheduled items, failing to provide ascertainable standard of guilt

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the drafting precedents furnished by the other Notifications considered in the- earlier decision of the, High Court  in Crl. Misc. Case No. 1470/68  do indicate that the draftsman did not intend the scheduled items in the Order as in force in May, 1969 to cover Tyres and Tubes of Motor Cars. But independently of this aspect the question may also be considered from another point of view, viz., if the legal mandate

arguments.claim: Criminal liability requires fair warning and reasonable certainty of obligations; mens rea or blameworthy mind needed; dealer must know obligations clearly

anchor.surface_text: According to the fundamental principle of our criminal jurisprudence, which reflects fair play, the dealer must know with reasonable certainty and must have a fair warning as to what his obligation is and what act of commission or omission on his part would constitute a criminal offence before he can be called upon to answer a charge and be liable to be convicted in a criminal court for any violation of a legal mandate. This approach is in conformity with the general requirement that the act or default should be associated with a legally blameworthy condition of mind.

arguments.claim: Certificate under Article 134(1)(c) improperly granted as no substantial question of law of great public importance shown; laconic order

anchor.surface_text: Unfortunately, even the High Court has made a laconic order on oral request, merely stating IT IS CERTIFIED That this case fulfills the requirement of Article 134 1 c of the Constitution of India and is fit for appeal to the Supreme Court. without showing on its face what substantial question of law or principle of great importance was involved justifying the grant of Certificate under Article 134 1 c . The word certify in this Article,

holdings.text: The draftsman did not intend the scheduled items in the Order as in force in May, 1969 to cover Tyres and Tubes of Motor Cars.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the drafting precedents furnished by the other Notifications considered in the- earlier decision of the, High Court  in Crl.Misc.Case No. 1470/68  do indicate that the draftsman did not intend the scheduled items in the Order as in force in May, 1969 to cover Tyres and Tubes of Motor Cars.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Drafting precedents from other notifications expressly list tyres and tubes separately from component parts and accessories, indicating no intent to include under item 1.

holdings.text: The legal mandate contained in the Order is not expressed with such certainty and clarity as to give reasonably precise and adequate guidance to those who want to be law-abiding and lay down an ascertainable standard of guilt by unambiguously specifying the Tyres and Tubes of Motor Cars as a Scheduled item.

anchor.surface_text: But independently of this aspect the question may also be considered from another point of view, viz., if the legal mandate ,contained in the Order is expressed with such certainly and clarity as to give reasonably precise and adequate guidance to those who want to be law-abiding. In other words, does the Order lay down an ascertainable standard of guilt by unambiguously specifying the Tyres and Tubes of Motor Cars as a Scheduled item.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Penal statutes must provide reasonable certainty and fair warning; ambiguous inclusion fails to meet this standard.

holdings.text: Dealers cannot be held guilty in a criminal court of an offence under the Essential Commodities Act for violation of any such mandate unless they are in a position to know with certainty that the items of Tyres and Tubes of Motor Cars are included in the scheduled items.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think it does unless the dealers are in a position to know with certainly that the items of Tyres and Tubes of Motor Cars are included in the scheduled items of which the price, list and the stock position are to be displayed in a companyspicuous part of their business premises, in our opinion, they cannot be held guilty in a criminal companyrt of an offence under the Essential Commodities Act for violation of any such mandate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Requires fair warning of obligations and blameworthy mens rea for criminal liability in line with criminal jurisprudence principles.

holdings.text: According to the fundamental principle of our criminal jurisprudence, which reflects fair play, the dealer must know with reasonable certainty and must have a fair warning as to what his obligation is and what act of commission or omission on his part would constitute a criminal offence before he can be called upon to answer a charge and be liable to be convicted; the act or default should be associated with a legally blameworthy condition of mind.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies general mens rea requirement to essential commodities offences, emphasizing fair play and certainty in penal laws.

holdings.text: The High Court was fully justified in recording the respondents' acquittal; no cogent ground for disagreeing with it; the appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: On the-view that we have taken, the High Court seems to us to .have been fully justified in recording the respondents acquittal and we see numbercogent ground for disagreeing with it. The appeal accordingly fails and is. dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds High Court's quashing of prosecution based on non-coverage and vagueness of the Order.

holdings.text: The certificate under Article 134(1)(c) was granted via a laconic order without showing any substantial question of law or principle of great importance; no material suggesting decision governs other cases.

anchor.surface_text: Unfortunately, even the High Court has made a laconic order on oral request, merely stating IT IS CERTIFIED That this case fulfills the requirement of Article 134  1   c  of the Constitution of India and is fit for appeal to the Supreme Court. without showing on its face what substantial question of law or principle of great importance was involved justifying the grant of Certificate under Article 134  1   c .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Certificate requires exceptional circumstances and judicial discretion showing substantial issue; mere error correction insufficient.

anchor.surface_text: But independently of this aspect the question may also be considered from another point of view, viz., if the legal mandate ,contained in the Order is expressed with such certainly and clarity as to give reasonably precise and adequate guidance to those who want to be law-abiding. In other words, does the Order lay down an ascertainable standard of guilt by unambiguously specifying the Tyres and Tubes of Motor Cars as a Scheduled item.
The appeal accordingly fails and is. dismissed.

The appeal accordingly fails and is. dismissed.
